io.spine.server.route

Class EventRouting<I>

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.spine.server.route.EventRouting<I>
  • Type Parameters:
    I - the type of the entity IDs to which events are routed
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    EventRoute<I,io.spine.base.EventMessage>, Multicast<I,io.spine.base.EventMessage,io.spine.core.EventContext>, Route<io.spine.base.EventMessage,io.spine.core.EventContext,java.util.Set<I>>, java.io.Serializable, java.util.function.BiFunction<io.spine.base.EventMessage,io.spine.core.EventContext,java.util.Set<I>>

    public final class EventRouting<I>
extends java.lang.Object
implements EventRoute<I,io.spine.base.EventMessage>
    A routing schema used to deliver events.

    A routing schema consists of a default route and custom routes per event class. When calculating a set of event targets, EventRouting will see if there is a custom route set for the type of the event. If not found, the default route will be applied.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • route

        @CanIgnoreReturnValue
public <E extends io.spine.base.EventMessage> EventRouting<I> route(java.lang.Class<E> eventType,
                                                                                          EventRoute<I,? super E> via)
                                                                                   throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Sets a custom route for the passed event type.

        Such mapping may be required for the following cases:

        • An event message should be matched to more than one entity, for example, several projections updated in response to one event.
        • The type of an event producer ID (stored in the event context) differs from the type of entity identifiers (<I>.

        The type of the event can be a class or an interface. If a routing schema needs to contain entries for specific classes and an interface that these classes implement, routes for interfaces should be defined after entries for the classes: 

        
 customRouting.route(MyEventClass.class, (event, context) -> { ... })
              .route(MyEventInterface.class, (event, context) -> { ... });
        Defining an entry for an interface and then for the class which implements the interface will result in IllegalStateException.

        If there is no specific route for an event type, the default route will be used.

        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of the event message
        Parameters:
        eventType - the type of events to route
        via - the instance of the route to be used
        Returns:
        this to allow chained calls when configuring the routing
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the route for this event type is already set either directly or via a super-interface

      • routeEntityStateUpdates

        @CanIgnoreReturnValue
public EventRouting<I> routeEntityStateUpdates(StateUpdateRouting<I> routing)
        Sets a custom routing schema for entity state updates.

        Setting a routing for state updates is equivalent to setting a route for events of type io.spine.system.server.event.EntityStateChanged. It is illegal to do both things simultaneously.

        Parameters:
        routing - the routing schema for entity state updates
        Returns:
        this to allow chained calls when configuring the routing
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if a route for EntityStateChanged is already set

        public R apply(M message,

        Obtains IDs of entities to which the passed message should be delivered.
